🗣️ This grid layout looks great on your device, but you‚Äôve been tasked to ensure that it looks great on many form factors, like a tablet. Are you confident that this code will do just that? If not, then what would you change about it to make it truly adaptive?
answerCode:
Solution,
 🥳 

Using GridCells.Fixed(2) forces exactly two columns, no matter how wide the screen is. On wide layouts (landscape, tablets), that makes each column too wide, stretching your cards unnaturally and breaking image aspect ratios.

The correct solution is to use GridCells.Adaptive(minSize), which calculates the number of columns based on available width and a minimum item width ‚Äî keeping your cards looking good across screen sizes.

            LazyVerticalGrid(
                columns = GridCells.Adaptive(minSize = 128.dp),
                horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.spacedBy(24.dp),
                verticalArrangement = Arrangement.spacedBy(24.dp),
                contentPadding = PaddingValues(16.dp)
            ) {
                items(shoes) { shoe ->
                    ShopItemWithImage(shoe)
                }
            }
